Sognafjorden, Hardangerfjord, Nordfjord, and Oslofjord are among the largest and best known. From the coast the land rises sharply to high plateaus such as Dovrefjell and the Hardangervidda. The coast changes from wild, rocky headlands and cliffs to hilly, forest-covered moorland.

The northern fjord system of Lofoten is the longest and best known in the Sápmi archipelago. Although a dozen fjords of this area are less than 20°N and all smaller than 45°N from Sørkapp Land, the largest and deepest are the northernmost: Nordkapp, Tysfjorden, Mörkøya, Grongarp, Sandnesfjord, and Helgeland fjords—which are considered part of the West Lofoten Zone. They represent the northernmost part of the Sápmi fjord system.

text:
Alfred, Lord Tennyson was born in 1809 at Somersby, Lincolnshire. Schooled at Louth and by his father, a rector, he began to write early, and at the age of twelve he composed an epic of 6,000 lines. In 1828 he matriculated at Cambridge but only after the elder Tennyson had approved his recitation by heart of the odes of Horace. Having graduated in 1833, he became an assistant teacher at a school in Suffolk, and was the first to introduce the public schools system there. He subsequently became headmaster of the City of Bristol Grammar School, where, while making a tour of the county of Kent, he visited a large class of pupils who were being taught for the first time in England. His experience as a teacher inspired him to write his greatest sonata, The Fall of the House of Usher, and for this he was awarded the Nobel prize in Literature in 1859. He was the leading English poet of the nineteenth century. He died in London on 20 December 1882 with a state funeral, which was attended by the Queen and other members of the royal family. He is the author of thirty poems; fourteen novels; six collections of his poems and short stories, including Our Village, The Idler, A Shropshire Lad, Imitation of Life. He is the author of the first English-language novel to receive the Pulitzer Prize and the first British novel to be entered in the New York Times bestsellers list, and The Idler (1841), the first in his series of novella-length novels which he began in 1870. He is also author of the well-known poem "The Palace of Art".

Contents

Treasure Island is narrated by Jim Hawkins. The events take place in southwest England and the Caribbean at some unspecified time in the eighteenth century. Jim is a boy who lives with his parents at the Admiral Benbow inn, in southwest England, near the port city of Bristol. During his adventures, Jim and his friends find his father the town's most important innkeeper, and the three are treated like honored guests.

In early 19th-century England, many men did not make good sailors. As a result, many ships would not dock at port for several winters. In the 15th century, Montserrat and Saint Martin were the only Spanish island of the Lesser Antilles. Later, during the 18th and 19th centuries, Montserrat was briefly ruled by Britain and France, by the Treaty of Paris (1763), as the French portion of Guadeloupe was called. After independence, Montserrat became independent, and was renamed the British Dependent Territory of Montserrat.

Before European colonization

The earliest recorded reference to both Montserrat and Saint Martin is in the Mayflower Compact. Though later colonists and historians have recognized the similarities between Saint Martin and Montserrat, this is not accepted by the authorities in both nations.

Prior to American colonisation of 1783–1850, there were two independent principalities, one by Spain and another by France, the other by England, known as Montserrat and Saint Martin. After the death of Eusebius in AD 380 and the fall of the last of the Antonines (the last of the family of St. Andrew in Constantinople), the Alexandrian bishops took center stage in the great dispute of Arianism (see Athanasius, Patriarch of Alexandria; Ephesus controversy). The Arianist view was that Christ was        merely a human being, in a material sense, rather than the Son of God. Arianism was maintained in Alexandria        by Theodore of Mopsuestia, who also became Patriarch of Alexandria, and who        was deposed at the Council of Nicaea in 325–27. When an elected hereditary peer dies, there is a by-election, using a variant of the Alternative Vote system, to replace them. The electorate differs based on the group of the hereditary peer. In the case of party or Cross-Bench peers, the electorate is the party or group that elected the peer whose seat is now vacant. In the case of Lord Lieutenant peers (the equivalent of an earl and heir apparent) and Lords Spiritual, the electorate is the Church or the Diocese of the church or institution represented by that peer who is now deceased—these can be represented by a single electorate, which does not have preferential vote thresholds in each election but can weight its representation differently against the electors whose own parties or dioceses do have thresholds in each election.

The main exceptions to the electoral system for hereditary peers are where an earl and heir apparent is succeeded by one of his male descendants, with the resulting change that the peer takes the place of no peer at all—in other words, the peer ceases to occupy a peerage, but is still in the Peerage of England.

In the Peerage of England the electoral system is broadly conservative; it favors a small but influential group of landowners, lawyers, churchmen or bankers, and a single-member electorate, which can include a range of candidates from all parties, with varying weighting depending on which party or church group has candidates elected.

In Scotland, the main party system was changed when the election of the King's Advocate was taken away from Westminster and put instead at a by-election, thus creating a single party system and also changing the electoral system, with the government parties now the largest party without party-specific threshold requirements, so parties are no longer allocated electoral constituencies, but each person who runs as a candidate for the party receives as much as 25% of them. A wonderful Portland restaurant once suggested that we make a liqueur similar to what the French call “Crème de Cassis” from Oregon blackcurrants. Of course we had to do it, and the result is truly wonderful: an intensely tart, lightly sweet, slightly earthy liqueur with huge fruit flavor. Our blackcurrants come from a farm less than half an hour from the distillery.

We started by freezing the berries and then straining them. After straining the berries we put half to six ounces of water to thicken the juice and bring it to the proper level for distillation. Then we added a couple of tablespoons of corn syrup to the juice to help set it, and gave the juice a vigorous shake. We were happy to find that the combination of berries, sugar, and corn syrup produced a liqueur that produced the requisite amount of alcohol (6% by volume).

We put an additional 2 ounces of corn syrup to 3 ounces of water and followed the rest of the recipe.
We are proud and excited to give our process a thumbs up.

Tasting the liquor

My wife thought this combination of fruits and alcohol was odd. It is tart and light…but not too tart! She enjoyed it. Then she tasted a little of a more concentrated liqueur we produced a couple of years ago that contained no more than a teaspoon (3 ounces) of water. To her, this tasted like water.

I am a little puzzled that the corn syrup and alcohol made a liqueur with so little water. Could it be that this water, used to help thicken the juice, made the liqueur slightly less sweet than the others we have made?

The exterior was a far cry from the conventional cars of the period, with its low overhanging hood and big rounded tail section that were intended to make it a stylishly modern looking proposition.

Sheepshead are found in the western Atlantic Ocean from Nova Scotia through the  northern Gulf of Mexico and south to   Brazil. They are absent in Bermuda, the Bahamas, the West Indies and Grenada. They tolerate a wide range of salinity and thrive in most of the habitats of the northern Gulf of Mexico, including  bays, bayous, canals,  other brackish waters, and occasionally fresh water rivers. They favor deeper waters, with densities up to 1,500 cells/ml.

Three vaccines are approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to prevent HPV infection: Gardasil ®, Gardasil 9 ®, and Cervarix ®. Gardasil combines three vaccines: a recombinant bovine papillomavirus (BPV 1, 2, or 4) virus as a vaccine to prevent infection with HPV types 16 and 18; the human papillomavirus (HPV) L1 virus-like particle as an oncogenic cell-intrinsic vaccine to prevent infection with a subset of high-risk HPV types; and human α(1,2)fucosyltransferase conjugate to the HPV L1 capsid protein to target fucosylation for delivery of an MHC-II epitope on HPV to stimulate a T helper cell response to HPV, which results in high-affinity IgG antibodies. Gardasil 9 combines three vaccines: a BPV 7 virus as an vaccine for protection against infection with HPV types 6 and 11; the HPV type 16 L1 virus-like particle as an oncogenic cell-intrinsic vaccine to prevent infection with a subset of high-risk HPV types; and the human α(1,2)fucosyltransferase conjugate to the HPV 16 L1 protein and HPV 26 L1 virus-like particle as an MHC-II--targeted vaccine to stimulate a T helper cell response to HPV.

Parliament is a city within the city of Strasbourg, a university city on the N and on its western outskirts. While the ‘city’ is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, the ‘country’ is not a country: it is the territory of the European Union, and that territory is at the heart of the EU’s single market and euro zone. For EU citizens who don’t have to take a day off to live here, Strasbourg is also the place to be for European diplomacy; the Union’s European Parliament and its seat in Brussels is just a few hundred kilometres to the east and the country’s parliament, the National Assembly, is also here. If you don’t like either of the two, Brussels or Strasbourg is also one of Europe’s major cultural, business and sport centres.

Strasbourg is also a tourist resort, with its many palaces, canals, forests, churches and towers, not to mention the town’s magnificent ancient cathedral, Notre Dame. While that cathedral is being rebuilt, and is expected to take thirty years, the city has had no difficulty in attracting visitors from all parts of Europe and all corners of the world – in the end, more than 50.000 people (most of them tourists) come each year. THE design of coins is determined by a tradition going back at least to the time of Charles II that the direction in which the head faces should alternate between the coinage of successive monarchs. The only exception to this has been the coinage of Edward VIII, who insisted on his likeness facing left. It is not clear whether this was an expression of rebellion against convention, or vanity, to show what he regarded as his better profile, containing his hair parting.

_The portrait of George III shows his hair parting_. (illustration credit)

**T HE ROLL OF HISTORY**

The first coins ever to be struck were a few pieces of metal taken from coins struck by the Romans, particularly the _equus_, a copper bronze coin, and the _denarius_, a silver coin. Although the metal of these new coinage was of bronze, these early coins had no definite design since they were not set in precious metals like silver and came in many styles and sizes.

After the Romans departed from Britain, there was very little further change until the Vikings were established there. They were a seafaring race (dating to around the ninth century B.C.) who were noted for attacking Britain's trading rivals in the Mediterranean and who had colonized Iceland and Greenland (and were noted for the fact that 'wanderers' or visitors from Iceland and Greenland were allowed by law to enter Britain). Their coins were gold and silver.

In 965, a Scandinavian army invaded Denmark. Although the Danes were not able to raise a full scale fighting force it was felt that the money raised could be used to finance the expedition. Therefore, while the invasion was largely a bluff – because in the meantime the Danes had sent letters to their rulers in the northern reaches of Britain – a limited set of gold coins was minted for the purposes of the expedition which were first issued in the year 985, or in the year 1000 when the invasion by Scandinavian armies was a success. Both types of coins were made in London, and later in Bristol.

During this Viking period, before and during the invasion, coins of high quality were being minted. So early did this occur that the king or the royal court were known to be wearing gold and silver coins, such as the _laudae_ and _curta_ coins which were minted during this period.

Cosworth has had a long and distinguished career in Formula One , beginning in 1963. Two Formula One teams were supplied with Cosworth engines in 2006: the Williams team using Cosworth V8 engines , transmissions , and associated electronics; and the Scuderia Toro Rosso team using rev-limited Cosworth V10s based on 2005 spec engines. The end of the 2006 F1 season marked the end of Cosworth's remarkable 43 year association with the series, as no team opted to use Cosworth for 2007.

Contents

Cosworth was not the first engine maker to appear in Formula One.

Early days

Formula One's founder, Juan Manuel Fangio, was already impressed by Rolls-Royce's R45 engine, as were most major companies in the early period. This was not the start of Formula One's engine revolution, however. In 1952, Ferrari had shown an astonishing engine fitted to a two-seat, rear-engined monoplane. Its speed was comparable to that of the much more powerful, two-stroke, rear-engined Fordson engine, but its fuel consumption was twice that of a Ford V8. This "Monte Carlo engine" was built as a prototype to test the concept of a rear-engined, two-passenger road car with a rear-mounted engine. Ferrari decided to use this engine in future monoplanes. An agreement was signed between Ferrari and a French aviation club to begin development of an aircraft-borne two-seat, two-seat high-speed racing aircraft. As the development of the aircraft progressed, the engine was adapted to form a two-seat, rear-engined racing car, the Scaglietti, and the first Formula One car was entered in the 1956 Monaco Grand Prix.

A year later the Lotus 55 was shown to Formula One officials. It had been a ground-breaking development of the 1951 Lotus 17, powered by a Rolls-Royce R, but the engine was not very powerful, resulting in poor mileage (10.9 miles per gallon, which was still high by the standards of those days) and a poor turning circle, while the car looked poor on the track. Despite these problems, however, the Lotus was an immediate success and it became the standard racing car in most modern countries until the 1980s when road-car manufacturers began their domination of Formula One. That was Ikeda, and I believe he deserves all the praise you give him today.

Umami? text:
The BSA's highest award was originally conceived as the Wolf Scout, as shown in the June 1911 Official Handbook for Boys . The August 1911 version of the handbook changed this to Eagle Scout. The medal illustrated in the handbook was a profile of an eagle in flight, but was changed to the current design before any were issued. In a September 1921 newsletter the BSA noted that the Silver Star for merit, first awarded in 1920, was a more appropriate award for Eagle Scouts. These designations are distinct because Scouts earn a Silver and then move on to a Gold. In a 1918 manual of rules and regulations, it called these Silver Scouts "Eagles" and stated: "A Scout who has earned the Eagle Scout medal, the most coveted Scout badge, should act as though he was a Gold Scout of the Boy Scouts of America." The 1918 handbook states that "a Scout with this medal should act as though he was a Gold Scout of the Boy Scouts of America."

The name Eagle Scout was dropped in 1940 as BSA's rank policy changed and the name Scout became an institution within Scouting itself, as the Scout Oath and Scout Law established the ideal by which all Scouts should be judged. This is why the BSA uses a badge now known as the Award of Excellence, which was designed to honor the original Eagle Scout as an ideal. There is now also the Award of Merit to give an example to show what a Scout could achieve by good conduct.

The Boy Scouts of America was founded in 1910 by Theodore Roosevelt and his friends, Theodore and Jane Bullitt, in response to a national emergency that threatened a youth revolution. They called their organization "The Boy Scouts of America" in early 1921 in order to distinguish it from The United States Boy Scouts. The second word, "Boy", was dropped in early 1938 and the word "Scouts" was dropped after 1936 as well, to reflect the association of Scouts with the Girl Scouts in 1909.

text:
As the Civil War began, poorer farmers were generally indifferent to questions of slavery and states' rights. The slaveholding planters held the most political power, however, and after some hesitation, Arkansas seceded (1861) from the Union. In the Civil War, Confederate defeats at Pea Ridge (Mar., 1862), Prairie Grove (Dec., 1862), and Arkansas Post (Jan., 1863) led to Union occupation of N Arkansas, and General Grant's Vicksburg campaign separated states W of the Mississippi from the rest of the Confederacy. In the postwar period, as Confederate forces began retreating toward re-established slave territory in Louisiana and Texas, some southerners hoped for reconciliation.

Slavery had always been contested. Northern supporters generally supported slavery; Southern critics supported abolition. This controversy was exacerbated by the Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 (ch. 5, 9 Stat. 441), which allowed citizens to sue for the return of runaway slaves. It also authorized federal agents, including such abolitionists as Senator Charles Sumner (R-MA) and Representative John P. Hale of Minnesota, to arrest and search suspected fugitives at any time.

In an 1836 speech Lincoln had stated that emancipation "in itself is self-evident. It seems to me it should be so. The children of this nation [are] growing up with the knowledge they are citizens." Shortly thereafter, he signed the "Emancipation Proclamation" on April 4, 1863. This proclamation ended slavery by national consensus and authorized the admission of free blacks to federal civil service and the military. Some Northerners criticized Lincoln for making emancipating slaves too easy. They argued that blacks should be made to work on agricultural plantations, so they could learn the skills needed to be free-workers rather than slaves. Southern supporters generally rejected this argument, however, while urging white southerners to remain slaves until they died. This debate continued for years after emancipation.

Emancipation in Louisiana

When Louisiana was freed in 1804, the state's slaves (1,900) and free whites (1,200) were held as property in private ownership. The Louisiana legislature, however, declared that no one could own slaves until they were fully emancipated. It was only after emancipation began in 1822 that more blacks could be freed.
